newsitem.title: USA: Central Europe flood losses seen at $10 bln - Scor.
newsitem.headline: Central Europe flood losses seen at $10 bln - Scor.

text.p: French reinsurer Scor SA estimates the total economic loss from floods in Central Europe at $10 billion, chief executive Jacques Blondeau told Reuters in an interview.
But he estimated the cost to insurers at $1 billion, saying much of the damaged property was not insured.
"The cost to us is minimal," he said.
Instead, he said, the floods are likely to create new demand for insurance and reinsurance in markets that previously had been closed under Communist rule.
"It's going to create a market," Blondeau said. People will realize "they need cover for this kind of risk," he said.
In Central Europe, "these markets are in the process of being created," Blondeau said.
"The insurance industry basically did not exist before. Since the move to a market economy they are discovering the need of being properly covered by insurance," he said.
And Scor, he said, has a strong position in the Central European markets and therefore may benefit from any increase in demand for insurance and reinsurance.
Poland, the Czech Republic and Germany have been among the regions hardest hit by the floods over the last two weeks.
German reinsurer Munich Re last week said early estimates of damage in Poland and the Czech Republic were for insured losses of 1.3 billion marks or about $714 million.
Munich Re said it expects to face claims of between DM 20 million and DM 60 million.
